explanation: Not correct. MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 specifically targets use of the standard <string.h> functions in ways that can access beyond the bounds of their destination/source objects. The code shown does not call any <string.h> functions directly; it calls helper functions (get_rq_uname, get_rq_param_unquoted_copy_z, etc.). Whether an actual out‑of‑bounds access exists depends on the implementation and contract of those helper functions. If get_rq_param_unquoted_copy_z itself uses a <string.h> routine unsafely (or writes more bytes than promised by params->...value.len + 1) then the violation would be in that helper implementation, not in this caller per se. From the snippet alone you cannot conclude a 21.17 violation; to prove the rule is breached you must show a call to a <string.h> function (directly or in a helper used here) that can overrun its buffer or demonstrate that the helper has no contractual bound and in practice can write past the allocated space. To make the call safer (and to satisfy MISRA-style checks) either ensure the helpers accept a destination size or document/verify their contract that they never write more than the supplied params->...value.len + 1.
